author: NEW YORK DAILY NEWS
title: Supreme Court nominee Gorsuch's stance on the issues
text:
President Trump praised his Supreme Court nominee Neil Gorsuch as having “outstanding legal skills” though how his nominee may rule on the bench may not be so simple.
He has spent more than 10 years as a federal judge, largely filled with rulings that fit with his reputation as a conservative “originalist” in the mold of late Justice Antonin Scalia.
Though the Harvard Law graduate has not ruled directly on many of the legal system’s most controversial issues, his record in the Denver-based 10th Circuit provides clues into how he may rule in future cases.
And though Trump will hope that his pick will uphold his agenda, Gorsuch’s most famous opinion in recent years lashed out at courts kowtowing to federal agencies.
President Trump nominates Neil Gorsuch to Supreme Court 
Immigration: 
One of Gorsuch’s biggest perceived differences from first runnerup Thomas Hardiman is on immigration, as Hardiman had previously worked with immigrants looking for political asylum.
The nominee’s record on immigration issues writ-large is not entirely clear, and neither is how he may rule on the constitutionality of something like Trump’s numerous executive orders.
However, he did write a widely-reported opinion last year focusing on federal authorities’ power in an immigration case and the so-called “Chevron doctrine.”
Senate Dems delay confirmation votes on Mnuchin, Price, Sessions 
Gorsuch wrote against the SCOTUS precedent from the 1980s, which told judges to defer to federal agencies’ opinions when laws from Congress are ambiguous.
Though much of his reasoning did not address immigration specifically, the nominee said that the doctrine appeared to be against the way the framers of the Constitution made a balance of powers between the branches of government.
Gorsuch said that the rule“certainly seems to have added prodigious new powers to an already titanic administrative state” and that courts had a duty to review how agencies implement laws.
Abortion and reproductive rights: 
Gorsuch has not spoken out about Roe v. Wade, which legalized abortion nationwide in 1973, during his time on the bench in Colorado.
Last year conservative, pro-life activist Andy Schlafly said that Gorsuch would probably not be as pro-life as he wants because he had avoided using the term “unborn child” in his opinions.
He also states that the potential justice is Episcopalian, and that the Episcopal Church is not as vocally anti-abortion as many other denominations.
However, other conservative writers have praised Gorsuch for wanting to review an injunction granted to Planned Parenthood when Utah tried to stop it from receiving federal funds through the state.
Gorusch has also written a book where he opposes assisted suicide and euthanasia.
Beyond abortion, one of his highest profile cases, Hobby Lobby Stores v. Sebelius, centered on access to contraception and plaintiffs’ religious views.
The case, where Gorsuch sided with Hobby Lobby, eventually went to the Supreme Court and ruled that businesses should not be mandated to provide contraceptive insurance coverage for employees if the owners decided it violated their freedom of religion.
Gun rights: 
The nominee does also not have a record of directly ruling on hot-button gun legislation such as firearm bans.
But his adherence to a “texualist” reading of the Constitution did lead to a gun-related opinion in a 2012 case about whether a felon had to know about his conviction in order to be prosecuted for having a firearm.
Gorsuch asked the court to review its decision saying that it was, leading legal observers at SCOTUS blog to say that, similar to Scalia, that he may down on the side of criminal defendants and their rights.
Legalized marijuana: 
Gorsuch’s position in Denver also means that he was one of the first federal judges to rule on issues regarding legalized marijuana.
A Colorado dispensary was made by the IRS to pay taxes on “business expenses” that they took off, and said that they should not have to disclose the nature of their business to authorities for fear of self-incriminating, according to Courthouse News.
Gorsuch and fellow judges denied the dispensary’s motion in 2015, though the judge was sympathetic.
His opinion focused on the Obama administration as a center of the problems, saying confusion stemmed from the Justice Department saying it would not prosecute
Trump’s administration is expected to take a tougher stance on local marijuana laws under possible Attorney General Jeff Sessions, who has called the drug “a very real dangers” and “not the kind of thing that ought to be legalized.”
